Review Sustainable processes for the catalytic synthesis of safer chemical substitutes of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone Carmen Moreno-Marrodan Francesca Liguori Pierluigi Barbaro ⁎ Istituto di Chimica dei Composti Organo Metallici - Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche (ICCOM-CNR), Via Madonna del Piano 10, 50019 Sesto Fiorentino, Firenze, Italy Istituto di Chimica dei Composti Organo Metallici - Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche (ICCOM-CNR) Via Madonna del Piano 10 Sesto Fiorentino Firenze 50019 Italy ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) is a chemical widely used as solvent in several industrial applications. However, many studies and regulations, including REACH, have indicated NMP as a potential toxic agent. Therefore, functional substitutes with high marketability are actively sought. This paper reviews the methods reported in the literature for the sustainable synthesis of the 5-methyl-homologues of NMP. Focus is on liquid phase processes using heterogeneous catalysts and bio-derived feedstock, i.e. levulinates, since N-substituted-5-methyl-2-pyrrolidones (5 M Ps) are readily obtainable from them through one-pot reductive amination. The contributions appeared up to July 2018 are covered and discussed in terms of reaction mechanism, catalysts' properties and applicability. Keywords REACH N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone Chemical substitution Levulinates Heterogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction Chemical substitution can be defined as “the replacement or reduction of hazardous substances in products or processes by less hazardous or non-hazardous substances, or by achieving an equivalent functionality via technological or organisational measures” [1,2]. In contrast with the reduction of the risk associated with a hazard, the replacement of a dangerous chemical is considered a primary prevention option, which is often referred as "Inherent safety" [3,4]. In the recent years, considerable efforts have been made worldwide in order to identify and classify chemicals of risk to human health and environment, and increasingly severe rules concerning their use have been implemented. These include the European Union Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals regulation (REACH), which have resulted to be an effective driver for substitution in both the academic research and the industrial sector [5,6]. Chemical substitution is based on a sequence of progressive improvement steps: identification of alternatives, analysis (including evaluation and comparison) and adoption [7,8]. It is a so-called "solution-oriented" process, i.e. the target is not on replacement with particular chemicals, rather the functions these chemicals can provide [9,10]. For market applications, besides safety and functional performance analysis, economical and technical feasibility must be considered, including use of non-fossil sources and environmental impact of production [11,12]. Substitution is critical in the fine chemicals and pharmaceutical industry [13,14], wherein the use of toxic substances or additives strongly contributes to increase both their E-factors (kg of waste generated / kg of product manufactured) [15] and the risks for human health [16]. Particularly, the market of harmless solvents is increasing both in Europe and North America due to the safety legislations that have been enforced on industries [17,18]. Most chemical companies have developed their own criteria and guides to benign solvents [19,20], e.g. GSK [21], Pfizer [22], Sanofi [23] and Astra Zeneca [24], while neoteric solvents have also been proposed [25,26]. A notable example of industrial solvent requiring substitution is N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). NMP is featured by a high chemical and thermal stability and is largely employed in various industrial applications. However, NMP is considered hazardous, which has boosted an intensive search for alternatives, including by funding of dedicated European projects [27]. In the present paper, we review the contributions appeared in the literature up to July 2018 describing the synthesis of chemical substitutes of NMP in relation of its use as solvent. Focus will be on the catalytic methods for the preparation of N-substituted-5-methyl-2-pyrrolidones in the liquid phase, particularly using bio-derived levulinates as substrate. No reviews have been previously published covering the specific topic, although some aspects have been partially described elsewhere [28,29]. 2 N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (CAS no. 872-50-4, Scheme 1 ) is a versatile chemical with several industrial, commercial and consumer applications [30]. Uses of NMP include petrochemical processing (acetylene, butadiene, lube oil), synthesis of polymers (polyethersulfones, polyimides, polyaramids), agro and pharmaceuticals intermediates (e.g. vitamin E), solvent (for resins, waxes, paints, adhesives, cleaning agents) and the manufacturing of graphene and lithium-ion batteries, which is foreseen to be a major push for NMP production [31,32]. Valuable solvent properties relate to its high stability and polarity, low surface tension and flammability. NMP is also increasingly adopted to replace dichloromethane or other toxic chlorinated and crude oil-based solvents [33]. All the above considerations, justify for a production of NMP of 200–250 kt / year, with an expected market size of 795.8 million USD in 2022 and a Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of 6.8% between 2017 and 2022 [34]. However, the high cost and the undesirable toxicological profile related to the manufacture and use of NMP rise concerns on its marketability and force producers to seek suitable alternatives to overcome increasingly restrictive regulations [35]. NMP is believed to damage fertility or the unborn child [36] and has been placed both on the "REACH SVHC: Candidate list of Substances of Very High Concern for authorisation" (classified as category 2 reproductive toxicant) [37,38] and on the “List of chemicals known to the state of California to cause cancer or reproductive toxicity” [39]. NMP is also subject to the chemical risk evaluation of United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) [40,41]. Due to its low vapour pressure (51 Pa @ 25 °C), inhalation and dermal absorption have been identified as the most likely primary sources of exposure [42,43]. A restriction on the use of NMP was issued in May 2018 by the European Council, unless exposure to workers is below 14.4 mg m−3 by inhalation [44]. 3 Substitutes NMP is an aprotic, polar solvent, fully miscible with water, which explains the large number of NMP uses. Several organic solvents (> 70) have been identified as potential alternatives covering the whole spectrum of NMP applications, particularly, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), acetone, methyl ethyl ketone (MEK), ethyl lactate, 1,3-dimethyl-2-imidazolidinone (DMI) and 2-(2-aminoethoxy)ethanol [45]. However, these options are not considered attractive due to their toxicological properties (e.g. classification as a carcinogen) or because of technical (e.g. thermal stability in the case of DMSO) or economic considerations. More recently, the related N-substituted-5-methyl-2-pyrrolidones (5 M Ps, Scheme 1) were proposed as substitutes for NMP. Unlike NMP, 5 M Ps are neither classified as toxic nor warned under the REACH regulation. No component of these products at levels greater than 0.1% is identified as a known or anticipated carcinogen by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) [46]. No restrictions or hazards are issued for N-alkyl-5-methyl-2-pyrrolidones by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) databases [47]. 5 M Ps are added-value products that are already employed as solvents, surfactants, key intermediates for pharmaceuticals, printing ink and fibre dyes [48,49]. 4 Sustainable synthesis by catalytic methods 4.1 Background On the industrial scale, 5 M Ps are currently manufactured by a two-stages, liquid-phase process involving the reaction of fossil-derived lactones (i.e. α-angelica lactone, α-AL) with aqueous alkyl amines, followed by hydrogenation over carbon-supported metal catalysts (Scheme 2 ) [50]. Typical yields are around 70% for the dimethyl derivative, using either Pd or Rh catalysts under 100 °C and 55 bar H2. Other synthetic methods have been reported based on the metal-free, photo induced hydroamination of aryloxy-amides using cyclohexadiene as hydrogen source [51] and the intramolecular hydroamination of benzamides using gold complex catalysts and microwave irradiation in dichloroethane [52]. Unsubstituted 5-methyl-2-pyrrolidone can be similarly prepared from α-AL, using ammonia and H2 reduction over Ni catalysts (150 °C, 121 bar) [53]. 4.2 Reductive amination of levulinates An attractive option to the synthesis of 5 M Ps is via catalytic reductive amination of levulinic acid or its esters, at least for two reasons. On one hand, reductive amination is a chemical process that allows for the direct, i.e. one-pot (single reactor unit) and one-stage (all reagents and catalysts are mixed together in a single operation), conversion of aldehydes or ketones to secondary amines by reaction with primary amines (Scheme 3 ) [54,55]. The procedure is conveniently carried out using metal catalysts and dihydrogen, borohydrides, silanes or boranes as reducing agents, with the clear advantage of no need of intermediate reaction, separation or purification steps. The method is widely used in organic synthesis for the manufacture of agrochemicals and pharmaceuticals [56,57]. Whenever a functionalised carbonyl substrate is involved, e.g. a keto acid, the resulting amine may undergo an intramolecular cyclisation, which provides a lactam as final product. On the other hand, the need to reduce dependence from oil feeds, while diminishing the costs, CO2 emissions and environmental impact associated with the manufacture of chemicals, has increased interest in lignocellulosic biomass as a renewable, alternative source of carbon [58,59]. Levulinic acid (4-oxopentanoic acid, LA) and its esters are versatile chemicals obtainable from wood-based raw materials, particularly non-edible agricultural residues and paper wastes, as well as from biorefinery side-streams [60,61]. Current technologies allow for the inexpensive production of LA on a tons/day scale by acidic dehydration of cellulose sugars (Scheme 4 ) [62,63]. Bioderived LA feedstock is available as aqueous solutions containing formic acid and variable quantities of H2SO4 used for lignocellulose depolymerisation [64,65], or as pure material, after purification [66,67]. A plethora of fine and consumer chemicals can be manufactured from LA, including solvents, fuels, monomers, additives, which earned it to be ranked among the "Top 10" platform molecules that can be obtained from carbohydrates [68,69]. 4.2.1 Catalysts and mechanism Both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts (typically metal nanoparticles onto insoluble support materials) have been reported for the liquid-phase reductive amination of levulinates to 5 M Ps, using alkyl and aryl primary amines and different hydrogen sources. Heterogeneous catalysts are clearly preferred by industry due to the easier catalyst/product separation, catalyst reuse, integration in existing reactor equipments and reduction of waste [70,71]. Usual reaction conditions for heterogeneously-catalysed synthesis of 5 M Ps are 90–150 °C, 3–85 bar H2 pressure, nearly stoichiometric amine / levulinate molar ratio. Conditions and performances for the most significant heterogeneous catalysts described in the literature are summarized in Table 1 , wherein catalysts' productivities are reported as mmol5MPs gcatalyst −1 h−1. The mechanism of reductive amination in the heterogeneous phase was elucidated by Corma, Iborra and co-workers using TiO2-supported Pt (0.2% wt) nanoparticles catalyst, ethyl levulinate substrate and solvent-free conditions (Table 1, entry 1) [72]. The process involves a three-steps reaction sequence. The first step is the acid-catalyzed amination of the levulinate γ-carbonyl by the primary amine to give the corresponding Schiff base, which is followed by the metal-catalyzed hydrogenation of the imine group to secondary amine. The third step is the acid-catalyzed intramolecular amide bond formation, with elimination of water in the case of levulinic acid (RH) or alcohol in the case of levulinate esters (R = alkyl), to give the desired 5 M Ps (Scheme 5 , path A). Based on a step-wise reaction study, it was demonstrated that the rate-determining step is the formation of the imine (path A, step 1), whereas the intramolecular cyclisation (step 3) is so fast that the aminoester intermediate is not detected. In spite of the formation of the Schiff base does not require the presence of acids to occur, the addition of an acidic catalyst showed to enhance the rate of imine formation, which suggests a key role of bifunctional catalysts in the direct conversion of levulinates to 5 M PS. Indeed, use of a truly bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst [73,74], i.e. "a combination of well defined supported acid and metal sites acting under the same conditions" [75,76], and particularly metal catalysts on solid acids, allows the process to be efficiently achieved by means of a single catalytic body, with no need of soluble acidic co-catalysts to be added, or mechanical mixtures of insoluble acids and supported metals to be used [77,78]. In the case in hand, it was hypothesized that protic acid sites are generated on the surface of Pt@TiO2 by hydrogen dissociation on Pt and spillover, as reported for other metal-supported species, which contribute to the acidity of the catalyst [79,80]. The favourable role of the acid in increasing the rate of amination step was confirmed by further studies using bifunctional catalysts comprising metal sites onto either Brønsted or Lewis acid support materials, particularly Ir nanoparticles onto sulfonated silica by computational analysis (Table 1, entry 3) [81], and Pd@ZrO2 catalyst via temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments (Table 1, entry 4) [82]. It must be noted that the proposed reaction mechanism is analogous to that commonly accepted, in the absence of the amine reagent, for the direct synthesis of γ-valerolactone (GVL) from LA over bifunctional heterogeneous catalysts [83,84]. The mechanism of GVL formation involves the metal-catalyzed hydrogenation of the levulinate γ-carbonyl group to 4-hydroxyvaleric acid (4-HVA)(rate-determining) [85], followed by an acid-catalyzed lactonization (Scheme 6 ) [86,87]. The process can be conveniently achieved over bifunctional Ru-based catalysts under mild reaction conditions (70–100 °C, 5–10 bar H2) [88,89]. GVL is a safe compound usable as solvent, flavouring agent and to produce liquid fuels, polymers, and a variety of fine chemicals [90,91]. An alternative pathway was also proposed for the reductive amination of levulinic acid to 5 M Ps using benzyl amine over Ni onto carbon nanotubes (CNT) catalyst (Table 1, entry 5). In that case, the first step is not an imine but an amide formation, followed by intramolecular cyclisation, dehydration and hydrogenation to pyrrolidone (Scheme 5, path B) [92]. The rate-limiting step was the hydrogenation one, which was attributed to the weak and strong adsorption of the alkene intermediate and H2 on the Ni surface, respectively, on the basis of density functional theory calculations. In this circumstance, the acidity of different support materials (determined by NH3-TPD) played a negative effect, which led to variable amounts of dimeric by-products. However, no quantitative relationship between 5 M P yield and acidity of the support was highlighted. Therefore, in the assumption that path A is the common one using heterogeneous bifunctional catalysts, and that the Schiff base formation is the rate-determining step, it may be thought that the role of the hydrogenation catalyst is less crucial compared to that of the supported solid acid in determining the overall activity of the catalyst, at least under the reaction conditions and using the metals listed in Table 1. However, the continuous withdrawal of the imine intermediate due to hydrogenation allows the first amination step to come to completion (which is often not the case), thus contributing to the performances of the overall process. By contrast, role of the metal sites may be critical as far as the selectivity of the catalyst is concerned, particularly when amine reagents bearing hydrogen-sensitive functional groups are used (vide infra, Section 4.2.2). It must be considered, however, that comparison among different solid acid catalysts is only meaningful if experiments are carried out in which all the other parameters are identical (for instance morphology), that is usually difficult to achieve [93]. For this reason, in the absence of systematic studies, the contribution of the acidic catalyst has not been completely clarified over bifunctional heterogeneous catalysts. Common drawbacks in using heterogeneous catalysts for the reductive amination of levulinates are the need of high reaction temperatures and H2 pressures, use of organic solvents, long reaction times, catalyst's stability and, in some instances, formation of by-products. Inventive catalysts were therefore engineered in order to circumvent these issues. Shimizu et al. studied the combination of various metals (Pt, Re, Pd, Rh, Ru, Cu, Ni), support materials (TiO2, Al2O3, ZrO2, SiO2) and co-loaded Lewis-acid metal oxides (V, Cr, Mo, W, Re). Catalysts screening revealed that best performers were Pt for the metallic function, Al2O3 as “nude” support and MoOx as secondary promoter. However, when combining together the different components, Pt and MoOX co-loaded TiO2 showed the be the most active ones, under relatively mild (3 bar H2, 100 °C) and solvent-free conditions (Pt-MoOX@TiO2, Table 1, entry 6) [94]. Based on the known strong Lewis acidity of molybdenum oxides [95], this was tentatively attributed to the activation of the levulinate γ-carbonyl by the acid-base interaction with the catalyst's acid sites. Nevertheless, no relationship between measurable acidic properties and catalytic activity was reported. Chen et al. described a ruthenium catalyst supported onto polymeric porphyrin-functionalized carbon nanotubes (Ru-PP@CNT), resulting in moderate to good high yields of the desired product, yet under severe reaction conditions (30 bar H2, 120 °C, THF) (Table 1, entry 8) [96]. While no significant activity differences were usually highlighted using alkyl or aryl amines, aromatic amines containing electron-withdrawing substituents showed to be more reactive compared to those with electron-donating ones in some cases [72]. The effect of solvent on substrate conversion has not been investigated in detail, despite use of green solvents (e.g. water, GVL), or solvent-free conditions, have often been reported. A perusal of Table 1 shows that Pd@ZrO2 (2.1% wt Pd) is likely the most productive under the smoothest reaction conditions (2–40 times in the case of n-octylamine) [82], which is attributable to the proper combination of acid and metal catalytic activity. This indicates the importance of a proper design of the bifunctional catalysts. A step forward sustainability and process intensification can be provided by carrying out catalytic operations under continuous flow [97,98]. Compared to conventional batch setups, continuous flow systems offer significant benefits either in terms of increased safety and reactor volume productivity, better heat transfer, simpler downstream processing, smaller gas hold-up volumes, easier scale-up and improved process control [99,100]. Active site inhibition may also be reduced thanks to continuous refresh of the catalyst surface [101]. Two examples have been reported for the synthesis of 5 M Ps via reductive amination of levulinates in continuous flow mode. Transfer of the above mentioned Pt@TiO2 catalyst from batch to flow operations resulted in lower 5 M P productivity (3.1 vs. 1.4 mmol g−1 h−1) using aniline reagent and comparable reaction conditions (Table 1, entry 2 vs. entry 1) [72], that was due to the high residence time (4.5 h) required to achieve a reasonable 5 M P yield (77%). The catalyst showed a remarkable stability over 10 h time-on-stream. A packed system based on carbon-supported FeNi nanoparticles gave N-phenethyl-5 M P in 99% selectivity at 91% conversion (0.7 mmol g−1 h−1), under quite harsh conditions (150 °C, 85 bar H2) and using an excess of LA (Table 1, entry 9) [102], however with outstanding retention of catalytic efficiency over 52 h. Despite dihydrogen is a cleaner reducing agent with lower environmental impact, formic acid (FA) was also used as source of hydrogen (and acidity) for the reductive amination of LA. Practical advantage of the approach is that LA/FA mixtures are directly obtained from the hydrolysis of cellulose, which allows for the in situ generation of H2 by metal-promoted / thermal decomposition of FA [103,104], thus avoiding any external H2 supply [105]. Drawbacks may include co-generation of metal-poisoning carbon monoxide, need of tolerant catalysts, corrosion and post-synthesis workup issues [106,107]. Following this strategy, 5 M Ps were obtained in good yields over Au@ZrO2 catalyst using equimolecular amounts of FA, LA and amine (Table 1, entry 10) [108], however water content should be kept at minimum, while catalyst's reusability was not investigated. Comparable results were observed using an excess of FA (4:1), high temperature (180 °C), H2O solvent and Ni Raney as solid catalyst (Table 1, entry 11) [109]. A similar protocol gave 5 M Ps in one-pot and two-stages using ketones or aldehydes as reagent, Ru@N-heterocyclic carbene polymer as catalyst (Ru@NHC) (Table 1, entry 12) and ammonium formate as both nitrogen and hydrogen source [110]. In this case, the primary amine was generated in situ, via reductive amination, by contacting ammonium formate with the carbonyl compound in the presence of excess of FA (Scheme 7 ). A second reductive amination gave the desired 5 M Ps by addition of LA to the reaction mixture. Despite the long duration of the overall process (12 h first stage, 24 h second stage), the final products were obtained in good yields at low reaction temperature (80 °C). Limited application of homogeneous catalysts was reported for the reductive amination of levulinic acid to 5 M Ps (Table 2 ). As a general observation, homogeneous systems show higher activities compared to the heterogeneous ones, although with frustrating issues in relation to catalyst separation and reusability, use under continuous flow, need of sophisticated ligands and demanding downstream processing. Good to excellent 5 M Ps yields were obtained using either aromatic or aliphatic amines, respectively, and a zwitterionic iridium complex bearing 2,2′-dipyridylamine and pentamethyl-cyclopentadienyl ligands under relatively mild, solvent-free conditions (Table 2, entry 1) [111]. Similarly, a HCOOH/HCOONa mixture in water was used as hydrogen source in conjunction with an iridicycle-aromatic ketimine complex, wherein the reactions only took place at pH ca. 3.5 using an excess of amine (Table 2, entry 2) [112]. Transfer hydrogenation from FA was also possible using a Ru complex generated in situ by reaction of [Ru(p-cymene)Cl2]2 with tri-ter-butylphosphine tetrafluoroboric acid salt (Table 2, entry 3) [113], or [Ru3(CO)12] catalyst with an excess of LA (Table 2, entry 4) [114]. Recently, PhSiH3 (3:1) was used as reducing agent together with In(CH3CO2)3 (Table 2, entry 5) or AlCl3 (Table 2, entry 6) molecular catalysts, however with significant drawbacks in terms of use of toluene solvent [115], need of excess of silane reagent [116], removal of siloxane waste generated. It is worth mentioning that the reductive amination of LA to 5 M Ps has also been accomplished using formic acid without any catalysts. A system comprising DMSO and tertiary amine was able to provide N-alkyl-5-methyl-2-pyrrolidones in good yields, however this requires a troublesome purification in order to remove the solvent and all unreacted starting materials [117]. In another work, an equimolar mixture of LA, amine and FA gave high yields of N-alkyl-5 M Ps, however at very high reaction temperatures (160–200 °C) and with concurrent development of significant pressures (20–35 bar) [118]. 4.2.2 Selectivity issues As above outlined, in the presence of a bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst, and under the concurrent conditions of hydrogenation and amination, levulinate substrates may undergo two main competitive reaction steps: the metal-catalysed reduction of the γ-carbonyl group to the corresponding alcohol (leading to GVL) or the acid-catalysed condensation with the amine to form the corresponding Schiff base (which then leads to pyrrolidones) (Scheme 8 ). The composition of the catalytic mixture is ruled by the relative rates of these two processes [55]. The hydrogenation route may be favoured by a subtle combination of reaction conditions and metal catalyst adopted [78]. Actually, using the catalysts and the conditions reported in Table 1, no significant formation of alcohol (or GVL) was detected. This indicates that the rate of levulinate condensation is usually higher than that of the competing hydrogenation reaction. However, use of a metal catalyst with high affinity toward CO bond hydrogenation can reverse the order. This may be the case of ruthenium, which is in fact largely used in the synthesis of GVL from LA (see Scheme 6) [89,119]. Indeed, Ru/C was reported to be far less selective, compared to either Rh/C, Pd/C or Pt/C, in both the reductive amination of 4-methylcyclohexanone with NH3 [120] and acetone with aniline [121], due to prevalent ketone hydrogenation. No information on the by-products observed was provided using the supported Ru catalyst reported in Table 1, entry 8. By contrast, the rate of amination reaction, hence the selectivity to 5 M Ps, can be increased with respect to that of hydrogenation by adoption of a solid support with strong acid catalysis properties. This is, for example, the case above discussed for Pd@ZrO2 catalyst, compared to the parent Pd@Al2O3 and Pd@SiO2 [82]. According to the above findings, selectivity issues in reductive amination of levulinates are usually limited to the presence of reducible / H2-sensitive functional groups on the amine reagent. Thus, high selectivity to 5 M Ps (86–100 %) was generally observed using unfunctionalised linear alkyl amines (propyl, butyl, hexyl, octyl) [72,82,94,96]. Branched [94] and cyclic (pentyl, hexyl, heptyl, octyl, dodecyl) [72,94,96] alkyl amines provided selectivity in the range 77–82 % and 56–97%, respectively. Analogously, good resistance of the aromatic ring was shown by aryl amines, including heterocyclic ones. Selectivity for aniline was in the range 88–95% both under batch [72,82,94] and continuous flow conditions [72]. Representative data for benzylamine, using heterogeneous catalysts and H2-reduction, are summarised in Table 3 . When details were provided, impurities were usually attributed to unreacted intermediates. However, it must be kept in mind that a proper comparison of catalysts imposes that selectivity data are evaluated at the same conversion level of substrate. Substituents on the aromatic ring are generally also well tolerated, including cyano, carbonyl and alkoxyl groups [72,94]. Hydrodehalogenation side-reactions occur only to a limited extent [122]. Available data for the reductive amination of LA using 4-chloroaniline are reported in Table 4 , showing that the desired halogenated pyrrolidone can be obtained up to 94% selectivity at 96% conversion (entry 2). In some instances, a poor selectivity was observed that was attributed to the steric hindrance of the substituents onto the aromatic ring, e.g. for 2-alkyl versus 4-alkyl-aniline [72]. It is therefore clear that the supported metal may have a critical role in determining the overall selectivity of the catalyst, although lack of systematic studies hampers clear indications. On the basis of the mechanism depicted in Scheme 5 path A, it may be argued that, while being effective in promoting CN bond hydrogenation, the metal of choice should be less efficient in the hydrogenation of other functional groups (if any), under the same experimental conditions. This may be tentatively rationalized in terms of affinity toward CN (e.g. Ir), rather than CO (Pt, Ru) or CC bond hydrogenation (Pd, Rh) [123,124]. In some cases, a role of the support material has also been highlighted in determining the catalyst's selectivity toward functional groups, as e.g. in the reaction of ethyl levulinate (EL) with 4-vinylaniline over supported Pt catalysts (Scheme 9 ) [72]. Use of 0.2% (wt) Pt nanoparticles onto ZrO2, uncalcined and calcined TiO2 resulted in a selectivity of 37, 60 and 94% to the vinyl pyrrolidone 1a, respectively, due to decreasing amount of N-(4-ethylphenyl)-5-methyl-2-pyrrolidone 1b formed as a consequence of CC hydrogenation. This result was explained in terms of preferential adsorption of the imine group intermediate, with respect to the vinyl group, onto the surface of the calcined catalyst. Other heterogeneous catalysts were otherwise completely non-tolerant toward CC or C≡C bonds hydrogenation in aliphatic amines [94]. Similar selectivity trends were reported when using FA instead of H2 as reducing agent [108]. It must be finally noticed that a significant effect of solvent has been reported in determining the reaction products distribution. While some solvents showed to be non-innocent under the usual reaction conditions (e.g. alcohols may form ketals [72], and water greatly enhances the formation of GVL [92,111], no direct relationship between solvent polarity and selectivity has been detected [92]. Formation of dimeric by-products is suppressed using GVL as reaction solvent, as commonly observed in the catalytic conversion of other bio-derived feeds [125,126]. 4.2.3 Use of nitriles and nitro compounds An interesting option to amine for the reductive amination of levulinates is the use of ciano or nitro compounds reagents, taking advantage of the potential for their fast, in situ reduction to primary amines over supported metal catalysts [127,128]. Earlier studies using alkyl and aryl nitro compounds, molecular H2 and solid-supported noble metals resulted in low 5 M Ps yields under high temperatures (150–200 °C) and pressures (40–60 bar), in the presence of organic solvents (dioxane) [129,130]. More recently, 0.2% wt Pt onto TiO2 nanotubes (Pt@TiO2NT) was used for the direct conversion of EL and nitro compounds to 5 M Ps under relatively mild conditions (120 °C, 10 bar H2), however with moderate productivities in the presence of an excess of EL (Table 1, entry 13) [131]. Choice of nanotubes support was motivated by the strong adsorption of nitro reagent onto conventional TiO2, which led to the fast deactivation of solid Lewis-acid sites, hence to the slowdown of the Schiff base formation rate-determining step. Very good selectivity to 5 M Ps was achieved in most cases (59–98%), with nice tolerance for nitro compounds bearing hydrogen-sensitive groups (C≡N, CC, CO, halogen), wherein the only by-product detected in all cases was the imine intermediate (Scheme 10 ). Similarly, the chance to use ciano compounds was indeed explored, however with poor selectivity results, using commercially available heterogeneous catalysts [132,133]. Recently, the previously reported Pt-MoOX@TiO2 catalyst was successfully used for the in-situ conversion of LA and a variety of aliphatic and aromatic nitriles to 5 M Ps [134]. Good yields were observed under reasonable reaction conditions (110 °C, 7 bar), yet with moderate productivities (Table 1, entry 7). While writing the present review, two interesting examples of continuous flow conversion of LA to 1-ethyl-5-methylpyrrolidin-2-one in acetonitrile solution were reported using either supported Ru [135] or Pt [136] catalysts onto titania, showing remarkable conversion and selectivity under 90 °C and 50 bar. 5 Conclusions and perspectives Chemical substitution of NMP is of great current interest due to both the large market and the increasing constraints for its use due to toxicity. Besides safer toxicological profiles and functionality, reliable substitutes on the industrial scale shall be manufactured according to sustainability and green criteria [137]. The homologues 5 M Ps can be conveniently obtained in one-pot and in one-stage from bio-derived levulinates via heterogeneous catalysis and reductive amination route, thus representing an attracting alternative to NMP. However, the conventional catalysts show significant drawbacks in terms of tolerance of some functional groups and high temperatures / H2 pressures / excess of FA needed to achieve satisfactory productivities [138,139]. Therefore, the development of innovative systems with improved performance and versatility for this process is strongly desired. The survey of literature suggests that a key to success, as for other multistep reaction sequences in cascade, is the design of solid-supported bifunctional metal / acid catalysts with exact properties [140,141]. This is by no mean a trivial task, since a deep understanding and a careful control over both acidic and metallic sites, as well as a fine tuning of catalyst formulation, is often required [142]. Among the several factors that can affect the catalytic efficiency, the type and density of acidic sites, and the nature, dispersion and loading of metal sites shall be considered with care, as well as potential synergistic effects [143,144]. The support material may also play a critical role, e.g. in relation to morphological and porosity properties. However, lack of experimental data does not allow for safe correlations between the above factors and catalyst's activity or selectivity so far. Forthcoming studies shall be targeted at clarify these connections, thus paving the way to a rational catalysts design based on the combination of synthesis, characterization, modelling and chemical engineering [145,146]. The ultimate aim is to obtain catalysts of predictable efficiency based on tailored composition, structure and morphology. Practical applications are expected in the development of efficient continuous flow processes, as well as expanding the scope of the methodology to the synthesis of differently substituted methylpyrrolidones (e.g. 4-methyl-pyrrolydones) and larger lactams (e.g. six-membered) [112,116], while exploiting other renewable raw materials from biomass. coredata.dc:description: N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) is a chemical widely used as solvent in several industrial applications. However, many studies and regulations, including REACH, have indicated NMP as a potential toxic agent. Therefore, functional substitutes with high marketability are actively sought. This paper reviews the methods reported in the literature for the sustainable synthesis of the 5-methyl-homologues of NMP. Focus is on liquid phase processes using heterogeneous catalysts and bio-derived feedstock, i.e. levulinates, since N-substituted-5-methyl-2-pyrrolidones (5 M Ps) are readily obtainable from them through one-pot reductive amination. The contributions appeared up to July 2018 are covered and discussed in terms of reaction mechanism, catalysts' properties and applicability.
coredata.dc:title: Sustainable processes for the catalytic synthesis of safer chemical substitutes of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone
